DataElement.preferredName: Edit Over-ride Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program Diagnostic Procedure Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Data item required by SEER for tumors of certain sites for the years 1973-87. This item is no longer collected. See Appendix D of the SEER Program Code Manual for details.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Edit Over-ride Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program Diagnostic Procedure
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Data item required by SEER for tumors of certain sites.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The type of change made to an element.:To take precedence over and countermand, thereby allowing an activity to continue despite a warning or error.

Concepts.definition: The type of change made to an element.
To take precedence over and countermand, thereby allowing an activity to continue despite a warning or error.

Property.preferredName: Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program Diagnostic Procedure
Property.preferredDefinition: A cancer registry mandated under the National Cancer Act of 1971 to operate and maintain a population-based cancer reporting system, reporting periodically estimates of cancer incidence and mortality in the United States. The Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program is a continuing project of the National Cancer Institute of the National Institutes of Health. Among its goals, in addition to assembling and reporting cancer statistics, are the monitoring of annual cancer incident trends and the promoting of studies designed to identify factors amenable to cancer control interventions. (From a brochure of the National Cancer Institute, NIH Publication No. 91-3074, October 1990):Methods, procedures, and tests performed to diagnose disease, disordered function, or disability.

Concepts.longName: Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program
Concepts.definition: A program of the National Cancer Institute that provides information on cancer statistics in an effort to reduce the cancer burden among the U.S. population.
Any procedure or test to diagnose a disease or disorder.

DataElementConcept.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries

ValueDomain.preferredName: Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program Diagnostic Procedure (SEER 73-87) Code
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A cancer registry mandated under the National Cancer Act of 1971 to operate and maintain a population-based cancer reporting system, reporting periodically estimates of cancer incidence and mortality in the United States. The Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program is a continuing project of the National Cancer Institute of the National Institutes of Health. Among its goals, in addition to assembling and reporting cancer statistics, are the monitoring of annual cancer incident trends and the promoting of studies designed to identify factors amenable to cancer control interventions. (From a brochure of the National Cancer Institute, NIH Publication No. 91-3074, October 1990)_Characteristic or indicative of (e.g., a disease)._A particular course of action intended to achieve a result._SEER 73-87_A system of numbered categories for representation of data. [Explanatory Comment: Required by SEER for tumors of certain sites for years 1973-1987. See Appendix D of the SEER Program Code Manual.]

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual entities required by NCI operations and systems. Includes administrative, financial, organizational and quasi-scientific concepts required for NCI operations and systems.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A cancer registry mandated under the National Cancer Act of 1971 to operate and maintain a population-based cancer reporting system, reporting periodically estimates of cancer incidence and mortality in the United States. The Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program is a continuing project of the National Cancer Institute of the National Institutes of Health. Among its goals, in addition to assembling and reporting cancer statistics, are the monitoring of annual cancer incident trends and the promoting of studies designed to identify factors amenable to cancer control interventions. (From a brochure of the National Cancer Institute, NIH Publication No. 91-3074, October 1990):Characteristic or indicative of (e.g., a disease).:A particular course of action intended to achieve a result.:A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.longName: Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program
Concepts.definition: A program of the National Cancer Institute that provides information on cancer statistics in an effort to reduce the cancer burden among the U.S. population.
Characteristic or indicative of a condition.

An activity that produces an effect, or that is intended to alter the course of a disease in a patient or population. This is a general term that encompasses the medical, social, behavioral, and environmental acts that can have preventive, therapeutic, or palliative effects.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
